awd_titl_txt: Open Compass: Leveraging the Compass AI Engineering Testbed to Accelerate Open Research
awd_abstract_narration:
Artificial intelligence (AI) has immense potential to contribute to advances spanning progress in science, the national health, prosperity and welfare, education, benefit society, or secure the nation's defense. Research initiatives, conferences, investments, and products based on AI abound and are expanding rapidly, while the methods, performance, and understanding of AI are in their infancy. Researchers face vexing issues such as how to improve performance, transferability, reliability, comprehensibility, and how better to train AI models with only limited data. Future progress depends on advances in hardware accelerators, software frameworks, system architectures, and creating cross-cutting expertise between scientific and AI domains. One way to accelerate progress on these topics is to create an engineering testbed, which provides a controlled environment that allows investigators to explore solutions to these - and other - challenges.  Open Compass is an exploratory research project to conduct academic pilot projects on an advanced engineering testbed for artificial intelligence, culminating in the development and publication of best practices. 

Open Compass will: 1) engage pilot projects and research groups, documenting approaches, experiences, and lessons learned; 2) conduct training events, in-person and using the Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center's wide area classroom; 3) organize and conduct a workshop focusing on advanced AI technologies; 4) integrate experiences gained through open research collaboration with those of industry experiences to identify a comprehensive set of best practices; and 5) publish results and best practices in peer-reviewed journals, conferences, and technical reports. The broad community will benefit from publication of research results, experiences, and a knowledge base of best practices. The research community will gain access to new technologies on which to develop algorithms and applications, along with insight across new fields of those technologies' applicability and important trends for AI. Open Compass will promote workforce development through student involvement in pilot projects and training and provide feedback to industry for to enable more efficient future AI technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Artificial intelligence (AI) has immense potential spanning research and industry. AI applications abound and are expanding rapidly, yet the methods, performance, and understanding of AI are in the process of being fully brought to fruition. Researchers face vexing issues such as how to improve performance, transferability, reliability, and how better to train AI models with limited data. Progress continues to depend on advances in hardware accelerators, software frameworks, system and architectures, and creating cross-cutting expertise between scientific and AI domains. Open Compass is an exploratory research project to conduct academic pilot studies on an advanced engineering testbed for artificial intelligence, the Compass Lab, culminating in the development and publication of best practices for the benefit of the broad scientific community. Open Compass includes the development of an ontology to describe the complex range of existing and emerging AI hardware technologies and the identification of benchmark problems that represent different challenges in training deep learning models. These benchmarks are then used to execute experiments in alternative advanced hardware solution architectures.

The results of the Open Compass project revolve around seven major activities described below:

1. Development of the Compass Lab - The Compass Lab, also referred to as the Advanced AI Engineering Testbed, provides preliminary unique access through the Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center (PSC) to new hardware and software technologies for AI, backed by human expertise and partnering with faculty thought leaders to develop solutions. The Compass Lab provides access, for example, to the following innovative AI hardware:

- Graphcore BOW-2000 server, includes 4 BOW IPUs and 5,888 processor cores. This 1U blade server delivers 1.4 petaFLOP of AI compute, 3.6GB in-processor-memory and up to 256GB streaming memory.

- Cerebras CS-2 servers, through which the potential of the promising Cerebras technologies for massive DL models is explored.

- Large NVIDIA GPU memory server (80 GB per card), through which the impact of larger GPU memory is explored.

2. Compass Ontology - The proliferation of hardware technologies being developed presents a daunting combinatorial challenge if viewed from the perspective of planning to benchmark everything. The landscape is continuously expanding, and researchers are faced with myriad choices of general- and special-purpose processors and accelerators, commodity, and exotic memory technologies, high-performance interconnects between processors and also between nodes and with a variety of topologies, and high-performance data storage systems. The Compass Ontology of AI architectures has value in offering a language to frame experiments and assess performance in a useful, interpretable way.

3. Performance Measurement and Analysis Framework - Open Compass accumulated a wealth of performance information. As expected, it is critical to be able to do analyses with confidence in the experimental conditions, and experiments will only be repeatable for as long as the hardware technologies and software stacks on which they were executed are still available. Leveraging the work advanced on the first stage of the project, a reliable framework for performance measurement that captures all provenance information as metadata was developed.

4. ML Benchmark at Scale - A group of six different benchmarks that require large scale resources were selected from the MLPerf suite and reproduced on available hardware platforms. These benchmarks cover diverse machine learning tasks including machine translation, object detection, image classification, recommendation and reinforcement learning all with excellent applications to science and engineering research. These benchmarks are representative of compute and/or memory intensive machine learning workflows and served as a baseline for tuning the hardware solutions available on the Compass Lab.

5. Knowledge Collection - In the process of executing the different benchmarks considered, a number of experiences have been documented including guidelines on how to address common issues, resource monitoring, system configuration, and tactics to obtain optimal results. Every server type considered has peculiarities that can be exploited by following specific instructions.

6. Education and Dissemination - A web site for the project has been designed and published. New benchmark results, educational artifacts, and updates have been disseminated there for the general public consumption. The extensive benchmarking knowledge captured within the scope of this project has continuously informed major hardware acquisitions at PSC.

7. Science Engagement - The project engaged a group of selected researchers who are pushing the boundaries of their scientific domains by either incorporating advanced machine learning approaches or by expanding the scope of foundational machine learning algorithms and methodologies. The domains covered by the aforementioned engagements include digital pathology, computational biomedical imaging analysis, imaging-based clinical studies, radiomics/radiogenomics, artificial intelligence in clinical informatics/workflow, foundational research on generative adversarial learning, materials science, speech recognition, and deep learning for astrophysics.

Results of the Open Compass project are encouraging. The aims of the project continue to be of relevance past its conclussion as the technology landscape continuously evolve. Complementary Open Compass activities are expected to be advanced via synergistic projects.
